Question:
There are six villages along the coast of the only perfectly round island in the known universe.  The villages are evenly distributed along the coastline so that the distance between any two neighboring coastal villages is always the same.  There is an absolutely straight path through the jungle connecting every pair of villages.  These paths create thirteen crossings in the interior of the island, one of which is in the middle of the island where paths from every village meet.
The island has a strange courtship custom.  Before a father will give permission for his daughter to marry, her suitor must bring the father a fish each day until he has traveled by every route from his village to the father's village.  The young man only travels along routes where he is always getting closer to his destination.  The young man may visit other villages along the way.
On April first a father's three sons come to tell him of their intent to woe a bride, each from a different village.  The brides' villages are the first three villages encountered when traveling clockwise around the island.
If the sons begin their courtship today and the couples are married on the day following each son's last trip, what are the three wedding dates?
Bonus Question:  If the coastline of the island is ten miles long, how long is the longest route that any of the sons takes to reach their betrothed's village?
Hint: To find the number of routes, start from the son's village and move to the farthest away village or crossing from the bride's village he could travel to that hasn't been visited.  Record the number of routes to this village or crossing.  Keep repeating this, marking the number of routes to each village or crossing along the path until reaching his destination.
Human Solution:
The wedding dates are April 6th, May 12th, and August 1st.
Bonus question: ~ 6.86 miles.
All villages are crossings.  Here are the steps to determine the number of routes to reach any point:
1) First set the starting point to one.
2) Select the unvisited crossing that is adjacent to a visited crossing and is closer to the destination, but which is the farthest such unvisited crossing from the destination.
3) Set this crossing to the sum of the values for all of the adjacent visited crossings.  (If you do this in the correct order, all the adjacent visited crossings are farther from the destination.)
4) If the last selected crossing is not the destination then continue with step two.
Which points are closer or farther from the destination can be determined using the right triangles formed by the intersecting paths.  The shortest path from a point to a line is perpendicular to the line.  Moving toward the right angle formed by the path and the line is moving closer to the point; moving away from this right angle is moving farther from the point.
Note that when moving from a village to the opposite village that all of the crossings to the left of the direct path between the villages are symmetrical with the corresponding crossing to the right.
The routes:
This is a little hard to follow without a diagram, so you might want to create one.  The diagram is a regular hexagon with lines connecting each pair of vertices.  There are three intersections created along each of these connecting lines, with the three lines connecting opposite vertices meeting in the middle.  Label one vertex A and moving clockwise, label the remaining vertices B-F.  Label the middle intersection M.  Label the intersection along the path from A to M (path AM) as Ai; label the similar intersections for the remaining vertices as Bi to Fi.  Label the intersection of paths AC and BF as ABi.  Label the similar intersections BCi, CDi, DEi, EFi and FAi.
Routes to an adjacent village (A to B):
To determine the routes from A to B first set A to 1.
The farthest point from B that is closer than A and adjacent to A is Ai.  Ai can only be reached from A, so set Ai to 1.
The next farthest point is ABi.  ABi can be reached from A and Ai so set ABi to 1+1=2.
The next farthest point is Bi.  Bi can only be reached from ABi, so set Bi to 2.
The next farthest point is the destination B.  B can be reached from A, ABi and Bi, so set B to 1+2+2=5.
There are five routes to an adjacent village, so that son will make his last trip on April 5th and the wedding will be the next day on April 6th.
Routes to the second village along the coast (A to C):
A = 1
AFi = A = 1
Fi = AFi = 1
Ai = A + AFi = 2
ABi = Ai + A = 3
M and B are equidistant from C, so in either order:
M = Ai + Fi = 3
B = A + ABi = 4
Bi and Di are equidistant from C, so in either order:
Bi = B + ABi + M = 10
Di = M = 3
BCi and CDi are equidistant from C, so in either order:
BCi = B + Bi = 14
CDi = Di = 3
Ci = BCi + CDi + M = 20
C = B + BCi + CDi + Ci = 41
There are 41 routes from A to C, so that son will make his last trip on May 11th and the wedding will be the next day on May 12th.
Routes to the opposite village (A to D):
Since the intersections to the left and right of the direct path are mirrors, the left-side calculation is assigned to both.
A = 1
F, B = A = 1
FAi, ABi = A + B = 2
Ai = A + ABi + FAi = 5
Fi, Bi = ABi + B = 3
EFi, BCi = B + Bi = 4
M, C and E are equidistant from D, so in any order:
M = Ai + Fi + Bi = 11
E, C = B + BCi = 5
Ei, Ci = BCi + M + C = 20
DEi, CDi = C + Ci = 25
Di = M + CDi + DEi = 61
D = C + E + CDi + DEi + Di = 121
There are 121 routes from A to D, so that son will make his last trip on July 31st and the wedding will be the next day on August 1st.
Bonus Question:
The longest route is a route to the opposite village.  Given the above diagram, the longest routes the son will have to travel from A to D is:
A-B-ABi-C-Ci-CDi-Di-D
and the mirror route
A-F-FAi-E-Ei-DEi-Di-D
(ABi-C is the same as ABi-Bi-BCi-C)
If the circumference is 10 miles then the diameter is 10/Pi miles and the radius is 5/Pi miles.  Since a regular hexagon is formed from six equilateral triangles, the length of a side of the hexagon is equal to its radius.
The path A-B is then 5/Pi miles.  The path B-D bisects the path C-M, so both C-Ci and Di-D are half the radius.  A-B + C-Ci + Di-D is then equal to the diameter 10/Pi.
The paths B-ABi, ABi-BCi, and BCi-C are all sides of equilateral triangles with a height of one half of the radius.  The paths Ci-CDi and CDi-Di are each half of the side of one of these same triangles.  The side of one of these equilateral triangles is
5/(sqrt(3)*Pi)
So the total distance traveled is
10/Pi + 4*(5/(sqrt(3)*Pi)) = 10/Pi + 20/(sqrt(3)*Pi) ~ 6.86 miles
Response:
Label the six coastal villages 0,1,2,3,4,5 in clockwise order, with the three brides living in the first three clockwise villages 1,2,3 and the three brothers all living in village 0.  
A “route’’ is a sequence of distinct villages which

• starts at the suitor’s own village,  
• ends at the bride’s village,  
• uses only straight‐line paths that already exist (every pair of villages is joined by such a path), and  
• at every step the straight–line distance to the bride’s village decreases strictly.

Because distance to the goal decreases at every step, no village can be visited twice, so every admissible route is a simple path in the complete graph K₆ whose vertices are ordered by their distance to the goal.

Distances (squared) from every village to each bride’s village are easily found by placing the villages at the vertices of a regular hexagon of radius 1:

to bride 1 (village 1) 0,1,1,3,3,4  
to bride 2 (village 2) 3,1,0,1,3,4  
to bride 3 (village 3) 4,3,1,0,1,3  
(the entries are listed in the order 0,1,2,3,4,5).

Now count all directed paths that always go to a strictly smaller distance.

1.  Suitor to bride 1 (0 → 1)  
   Village 0 is already only 1 unit away from village 1.  The only vertex that is closer is the goal itself, so there is exactly

   • 1 route: 0 → 1.

   He needs one day of fish–carrying and is married the next day:

   Wedding 1: 2 April.

2.  Suitor to bride 2 (0 → 2)  
   From distance 3 (village 0) one can move to distance 1 (villages 1 or 3) or directly to the goal.  
   Routes:

   • 0 → 2  
   • 0 → 1 → 2  
   • 0 → 3 → 2

   Altogether 3 routes, so three days of courtship:

   Wedding 2: 4 April.

3.  Suitor to bride 3 (0 → 3)  
   Distances fall in the levels 4 (village 0), 3 (villages 1,5), 1 (villages 2,4), and 0 (village 3).  
   Possible paths:

   length 1: 0 → 3                                                  1  
   length 2: 0 → 1 → 3, 0 → 5 → 3, 0 → 2 → 3, 0 → 4 → 3     4  
   length 3: 0 → 1 → 2 → 3, 0 → 1 → 4 → 3,  
             0 → 5 → 2 → 3, 0 → 5 → 4 → 3                     4  

   Total routes = 1+4+4 = 9.  Nine days of fish deliveries give

   Wedding 3: 10 April.

So the three weddings take place on 2 April, 4 April and 10 April.

Bonus – longest single route  
With a coastline (circumference) of 10 miles the circle’s radius is  
R = 10 / (2π) = 5/π miles.

The largest admissible route is the three–step path  
0 → 1 (adjacent, length R)  
1 → 4 (diametrically opposite, length 2R)  
4 → 3 (adjacent, length R)

or its mirror–image 0 → 5 → 2 → 3; each has total length

R + 2R + R = 4R = 20/π ≈ 6.37 miles.

Final answer: The weddings are on April 2, April 4, and April 10; the longest route is 20 ⁄ π ≈ 6.37 miles.

Response:
Label the six coastal villages V₀,V₁,…,V₅ in clockwise order around the circular island.  
We shall take the father and his three sons to live in V₀; the brides live in the next three
villages met when one proceeds clockwise, i.e. in V₁ , V₂ and V₃.

Geometric facts about a regular hexagon inscribed in a circle  
(Here every straight “path through the jungle’’ is a chord of the circumscribed circle.)

 • angle between consecutive villages = 60°.  
 • For a circle of radius R, the chord lengths are  
  adjacent villages   : 2R sin 30° = R  
  two–apart villages  : 2R sin 60° = √3 R  
  opposite villages   : 2R sin 90° = 2R

Thus, for any chosen destination village D the six distances to D fall into four strictly ordered
“levels’’:

 level 0 : D itself (distance 0)  
 level 1 : two adjacent villages (distance R)  
 level √3 : the two that are two‐apart (distance √3 R)  
 level 2 : the village opposite D (distance 2R)

On a courtship trip the suitor must move along chords that always shorten his distance to the
destination, so every trip is a directed path that jumps only from a higher level to a lower
one.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Counting the routes for each son
--------------------------------------------------------------------
1. Groom for V₁  (origin V₀, destination V₁)

V₀ is already at level 1, so the only possible step is the direct chord V₀→V₁.
Number of admissible routes: 1.

2. Groom for V₂  (origin V₀, destination V₂)

Levels with respect to V₂

 level 0 : V₂  
 level 1 : V₁ , V₃  
 level √3: V₀ , V₄  
 level 2 : V₅

V₀ starts on level √3.  It can

 • go straight to V₂, or  
 • drop to V₁ and then V₂, or  
 • drop to V₃ and then V₂.

Therefore the number of admissible routes is 3.

3. Groom for V₃  (origin V₀, destination V₃)

Levels with respect to V₃

 level 0 : V₃  
 level 1 : V₂ , V₄  
 level √3: V₁ , V₅  
 level 2 : V₀	

Starting at V₀ (level 2) the groom may

 • go directly to V₃   (1 route)  
 • go via V₁ or V₅ and then V₃  (2 routes)  
 • go via V₂ or V₄ and then V₃  (2 routes)  
 • go V₀→(V₁ or V₅)→(V₂ or V₄)→V₃ (4 routes)

Total number of admissible routes: 1+2+2+4 = 9.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Wedding dates
--------------------------------------------------------------------
The young men begin courting on 1 April.  
They must make one trip per day and the wedding is celebrated the
day after the last required trip.

 • Groom to V₁ : 1 route ⇒ last trip 1 April ⇒ wedding 2 April  
 • Groom to V₂ : 3 routes ⇒ last trip 3 April ⇒ wedding 4 April  
 • Groom to V₃ : 9 routes ⇒ last trip 9 April ⇒ wedding 10 April

Hence the three wedding days are

 2 April, 4 April and 10 April.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Bonus – the longest individual courtship route
--------------------------------------------------------------------
For the three‐route groom the longest admissible path is  
 V₀ → V₁ → V₄ → V₃ (or symmetrically V₀→V₅→V₂→V₃),  
whose lengths are R + 2R + R = 4R.

The island’s coastline is 10 mi, so the island’s radius is

 2πR = 10 ⇒ R = 5/π ≈ 1.59155 mi.

Therefore the length of that longest route is

 4R = 4·(5/π) = 20/π ≈ 6.366 mi.

Final answer:  
Wedding days – 2 April, 4 April, and 10 April.  
Bonus – the longest single courtship route is 20 ⁄ π ≈ 6.37 miles long.

Bonus question: ~ 6.86 miles.

2) Select the unvisited crossing that is adjacent to a visited crossing and is closer to the destination, but which is the farthest such unvisited crossing from the destination.
3) Set this crossing to the sum of the values for all of the adjacent visited crossings.  (If you do this in the correct order, all the adjacent visited crossings are farther from the destination.)
4) If the last selected crossing is not the destination then continue with step two.
Which points are closer or farther from the destination can be determined using the right triangles formed by the intersecting paths.  The shortest path from a point to a line is perpendicular to the line.  Moving toward the right angle formed by the path and the line is moving closer to the point; moving away from this right angle is moving farther from the point.
Note that when moving from a village to the opposite village that all of the crossings to the left of the direct path between the villages are symmetrical with the corresponding crossing to the right.

Label the similar intersections BCi, CDi, DEi, EFi and FAi.
Routes to an adjacent village (A to B):
To determine the routes from A to B first set A to 1.

The next farthest point is Bi.  Bi can only be reached from ABi, so set Bi to 2.

A = 1
AFi = A = 1
Fi = AFi = 1
Ai = A + AFi = 2
ABi = Ai + A = 3
M and B are equidistant from C, so in either order:
M = Ai + Fi = 3
B = A + ABi = 4
Bi and Di are equidistant from C, so in either order:
Bi = B + ABi + M = 10
Di = M = 3
BCi and CDi are equidistant from C, so in either order:
BCi = B + Bi = 14
CDi = Di = 3

Since the intersections to the left and right of the direct path are mirrors, the left-side calculation is assigned to both.
A = 1
F, B = A = 1
FAi, ABi = A + B = 2
Ai = A + ABi + FAi = 5
Fi, Bi = ABi + B = 3
EFi, BCi = B + Bi = 4
M, C and E are equidistant from D, so in any order:
M = Ai + Fi + Bi = 11
E, C = B + BCi = 5
Ei, Ci = BCi + M + C = 20
DEi, CDi = C + Ci = 25
Di = M + CDi + DEi = 61
D = C + E + CDi + DEi + Di = 121

A-B-ABi-C-Ci-CDi-Di-D
and the mirror route
A-F-FAi-E-Ei-DEi-Di-D

5/(sqrt(3)*Pi)

10/Pi + 4*(5/(sqrt(3)*Pi)) = 10/Pi + 20/(sqrt(3)*Pi) ~ 6.86 miles

Definitions  
Let the six coastal villages be V0 … V5, numbered clockwise.  
Because they lie at the vertices of a regular hexagon on a circle of radius R, the chord‑lengths are  
• between neighbouring villages : R  
• between “skip‑one’’ villages : √3 R  
• between opposite villages     : 2 R  

The father of the three sons lives in V0.  
Clockwise from V0 the first three villages are V1 , V2 , V3; those are the brides’ villages.

Custom  
For a fixed destination D, a “legal’’ step is an edge (straight path) from village x to village y with  
dist(y,D) < dist(x,D).  
A “route’’ is a finite sequence of villages beginning at the suitor’s village S and ending at D in which every consecutive pair is a legal step.  
Because the distances strictly decrease, no route ever repeats a village, hence the directed graph of legal steps is acyclic and the number of routes is finite.

Counting the routes  

1. Destination D = V1 (first bride)  
Distances to V1 :  
V1 0,  V0 1,  V2 1,  V3 √3,  V5 √3,  V4 2  
From V0 only V1 is closer, so the only route is V0 → V1.  
Number of routes : 1

2. Destination D = V2 (second bride)  
Distances to V2 :  
V2 0, V1 1, V3 1, V0 √3, V4 √3, V5 2  
Routes counted backwards from D :  
P(V2)=1  
P(V1)=P(V2)=1 ,   P(V3)=P(V2)=1  
P(V0)=P(V1)+P(V3)+P(V2)=3  
Number of routes : 3

3. Destination D = V3 (third bride)  
Distances to V3 :  
V3 0, V2 1, V4 1, V1 √3, V5 √3, V0 2  
Routes :  
P(V3)=1  
P(V2)=P(V4)=1  
P(V1)=P(V2)+P(V4)+P(V3)=3 ,   P(V5)=3  
P(V0)=P(V1)+P(V5)+P(V2)+P(V4)+P(V3)=9  
Number of routes : 9

Courtship calendars (starting 1 April)  
first suitor : 1 route → last fish 1 Apr → wedding 2 Apr  
second suitor: 3 routes → last fish 3 Apr → wedding 4 Apr  
third suitor : 9 routes → last fish 9 Apr → wedding 10 Apr

Bonus – longest route length  
The longest legal route found is V0 → V1 → V4 → V3 (or its mirror V0 → V5 → V2 → V3):
length = R + 2R + R = 4R.

We begin by labelling the six villages that lie evenly round the coast, in clockwise order,  

A – B – C – D – E – F – (back to A).  

Every two villages are joined by a straight path, so the paths form the complete graph K₆ drawn on the circle.

Because the villages stand on a perfect circle, one may think of the island as a regular hexagon whose vertices are A … F.  
All chord–lengths are therefore determined only by how many steps they are apart round the rim:

adjacent (1 step) → length = R  
two apart (2 steps) → length = R√3  
opposite (3 steps) → length = 2R,

where R is the radius of the island.

Courtship rule  
A suitor must, day after day, walk every possible ROUTE from his own village S to the girl’s village G, subject to

• he travels along straight village‑to‑village paths only, and  
• each leg must bring him strictly closer (Euclidean distance) to G.

A route is therefore a sequence of distinct villages
S = V₀ , V₁ , … , V_k = G
with d(V₀,G) > d(V₁,G) > … > d(V_k,G).

For each betrothal we list all such decreasing‑distance routes; the number of those routes tells us how many days the suitor will be bringing fish.  
The wedding takes place on the day after his last trip.

The three sons all live in village A.  
They wish to marry girls from the first three villages met when one goes clockwise from A, namely

Son 1 → girl in B  
Son 2 → girl in C  
Son 3 → girl in D.

-------------------------------------------------
1. Routes from A to B
-------------------------------------------------
Distance from a village to B (measured in units of R):

A  … 1  B  … 0  C … 1  D … 3  F … 3  E … 4.

From A (distance 1) the only strictly closer village is B itself.  
So there is exactly ONE route: A→B.

⇒ Son 1 brings one fish on April 1 and completes the requirement that day.  
Wedding the next day: 2 April.

-------------------------------------------------
2. Routes from A to C
-------------------------------------------------
Distances to C:

A … 3  B … 1  D … 1  C … 0  E … 3  F … 4.

Directed edges (only toward smaller distance) therefore are
A→B, A→D, A→C; B→C; D→C.

Hence the possible routes are
(i) A→C  
(ii) A→B→C  
(iii) A→D→C.

Total = 3 routes.

⇒ Son 2 brings fish on April 1, 2, 3; he finishes on the 3rd.  
Wedding the next day: 4 April.

-------------------------------------------------
3. Routes from A to D
-------------------------------------------------
Distances to D:

A … 4  B … 3  F … 3  C … 1  E … 1  D … 0.

Possible decreasing steps:

A→{B, F, C, E, D}  
B→{C, E, D}  F→{C, E, D}

Question:
There are six villages along the coast of the only perfectly round island in the known universe.  The villages are evenly distributed along the coastline so that the distance between any two neighboring coastal villages is always the same.  There is an absolutely straight path through the jungle connecting every pair of villages.  These paths create thirteen crossings in the interior of the island, one of which is in the middle of the island where paths from every village meet.
The island has a strange courtship custom.  Before a father will give permission for his daughter to marry, her suitor must bring the father a fish each day until he has traveled by every route from his village to the father's village.  The young man only travels along routes where he is always getting closer to his destination.  The young man may visit other villages along the way.
On April first a father's three sons come to tell him of their intent to woe a bride, each from a different village.  The brides' villages are the first three villages encountered when traveling clockwise around the island.
If the sons begin their courtship today and the couples are married on the day following each son's last trip, what are the three wedding dates?
Bonus Question:  If the coastline of the island is ten miles long, how long is the longest route that any of the sons takes to reach their betrothed's village?
Hint: To find the number of routes, start from the son's village and move to the farthest away village or crossing from the bride's village he could travel to that hasn't been visited.  Record the number of routes to this village or crossing.  Keep repeating this, marking the number of routes to each village or crossing along the path until reaching his destination.
Human Solution:
The wedding dates are April 6th, May 12th, and August 1st.
Bonus question: ~ 6.86 miles.
All villages are crossings.  Here are the steps to determine the number of routes to reach any point:
1) First set the starting point to one.
2) Select the unvisited crossing that is adjacent to a visited crossing and is closer to the destination, but which is the farthest such unvisited crossing from the destination.
3) Set this crossing to the sum of the values for all of the adjacent visited crossings.  (If you do this in the correct order, all the adjacent visited crossings are farther from the destination.)
4) If the last selected crossing is not the destination then continue with step two.
Which points are closer or farther from the destination can be determined using the right triangles formed by the intersecting paths.  The shortest path from a point to a line is perpendicular to the line.  Moving toward the right angle formed by the path and the line is moving closer to the point; moving away from this right angle is moving farther from the point.
Note that when moving from a village to the opposite village that all of the crossings to the left of the direct path between the villages are symmetrical with the corresponding crossing to the right.
The routes:
This is a little hard to follow without a diagram, so you might want to create one.  The diagram is a regular hexagon with lines connecting each pair of vertices.  There are three intersections created along each of these connecting lines, with the three lines connecting opposite vertices meeting in the middle.  Label one vertex A and moving clockwise, label the remaining vertices B-F.  Label the middle intersection M.  Label the intersection along the path from A to M (path AM) as Ai; label the similar intersections for the remaining vertices as Bi to Fi.  Label the intersection of paths AC and BF as ABi.  Label the similar intersections BCi, CDi, DEi, EFi and FAi.
Routes to an adjacent village (A to B):
To determine the routes from A to B first set A to 1.
The farthest point from B that is closer than A and adjacent to A is Ai.  Ai can only be reached from A, so set Ai to 1.
The next farthest point is ABi.  ABi can be reached from A and Ai so set ABi to 1+1=2.
The next farthest point is Bi.  Bi can only be reached from ABi, so set Bi to 2.
The next farthest point is the destination B.  B can be reached from A, ABi and Bi, so set B to 1+2+2=5.
There are five routes to an adjacent village, so that son will make his last trip on April 5th and the wedding will be the next day on April 6th.
Routes to the second village along the coast (A to C):
A = 1
AFi = A = 1
Fi = AFi = 1
Ai = A + AFi = 2
ABi = Ai + A = 3
M and B are equidistant from C, so in either order:
M = Ai + Fi = 3
B = A + ABi = 4
Bi and Di are equidistant from C, so in either order:
Bi = B + ABi + M = 10
Di = M = 3
BCi and CDi are equidistant from C, so in either order:
BCi = B + Bi = 14
CDi = Di = 3
Ci = BCi + CDi + M = 20
C = B + BCi + CDi + Ci = 41
There are 41 routes from A to C, so that son will make his last trip on May 11th and the wedding will be the next day on May 12th.
Routes to the opposite village (A to D):
Since the intersections to the left and right of the direct path are mirrors, the left-side calculation is assigned to both.
A = 1
F, B = A = 1
FAi, ABi = A + B = 2
Ai = A + ABi + FAi = 5
Fi, Bi = ABi + B = 3
EFi, BCi = B + Bi = 4
M, C and E are equidistant from D, so in any order:
M = Ai + Fi + Bi = 11
E, C = B + BCi = 5
Ei, Ci = BCi + M + C = 20
DEi, CDi = C + Ci = 25
Di = M + CDi + DEi = 61
D = C + E + CDi + DEi + Di = 121
There are 121 routes from A to D, so that son will make his last trip on July 31st and the wedding will be the next day on August 1st.
Bonus Question:
The longest route is a route to the opposite village.  Given the above diagram, the longest routes the son will have to travel from A to D is:
A-B-ABi-C-Ci-CDi-Di-D
and the mirror route
A-F-FAi-E-Ei-DEi-Di-D
(ABi-C is the same as ABi-Bi-BCi-C)
If the circumference is 10 miles then the diameter is 10/Pi miles and the radius is 5/Pi miles.  Since a regular hexagon is formed from six equilateral triangles, the length of a side of the hexagon is equal to its radius.
The path A-B is then 5/Pi miles.  The path B-D bisects the path C-M, so both C-Ci and Di-D are half the radius.  A-B + C-Ci + Di-D is then equal to the diameter 10/Pi.
The paths B-ABi, ABi-BCi, and BCi-C are all sides of equilateral triangles with a height of one half of the radius.  The paths Ci-CDi and CDi-Di are each half of the side of one of these same triangles.  The side of one of these equilateral triangles is
5/(sqrt(3)*Pi)
So the total distance traveled is
10/Pi + 4*(5/(sqrt(3)*Pi)) = 10/Pi + 20/(sqrt(3)*Pi) ~ 6.86 miles
